item.title: One Killed After Thai, Cambodian Soldiers Clash at Border
item.description: Thai and Cambodian soldiers exchanged fire at a disputed border area early on Wednesday, leaving one Cambodian soldier dead and prompting both sides to hold talks to end the standoff.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana

media:content.media:description: Thai soldiers.

item.title: Merz’s Government Set to Drop Fast-Track Path to Citizenship
item.description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s cabinet moved to abolish a measure that allowed well-integrated migrants to qualify for citizenship after three years in the country, according to government officials.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: Photo by Matthias Balk/picture alliance via Getty Images) Photographer: picture alliance/dpa/picture alliance

item.title: Iran May Allow American IAEA Monitors Under New Nuclear Deal
item.description: Iran will consider allowing the International Atomic Energy Agency to send US inspectors to monitor the country’s atomic activity if a new nuclear deal is brokered with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: The Bushehr nuclear power plant in Iran. Photographer: Morteza Nikoubazl/Getty Images

item.title: Zelenskiy Embarks on a Key Month for Ukraine
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska

media:content.media:description: Relatives and military personnel welcome Ukrainian servicemen following a major prisoner of war (POW) swap with Russia at an undisclosed location in Ukraine, on Friday, May 23, 2025. Ukraine’s capital was targeted by a Russian drone and missile barrage overnight, hours after the warring sides started a large prisoner swap that’s due to continue over the weekend. Photographer: Andrew Kravchenko/Bloomberg

item.title: EU Plans to Create a Maritime Security Hub in the Black Sea
item.description: The European Union wants to create a maritime security hub in the Black Sea to monitor potential threats and protect critical infrastructure, Kaja Kallas, the EU’s top diplomat, told reporters on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano

media:content.media:description: French Navy aircraft carrier Charles-de-Gaulle. Photographer: Clement Mahoudeau/Getty Images

item.title: Finland Starts Process to Withdraw From Landmine Ban Treaty
item.description: Finland started the process of withdrawing from the Ottawa Convention, which bans anti-personnel landmines.
item.dc:creator: Kati Pohjanpalo

media:content.media:description: Landmines in Ukraine.

item.title: Malaysian Ministers Quit in Blow to Anwar’s Government
item.description: Malaysia’s Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli and Natural Resources and Environmental Sustainability Minister Nik Nazmi Nik Ahmad are leaving the cabinet, days after they were defeated in an internal party election that was marred by allegations of vote-rigging and nepotism.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

media:content.media:description: Rafizi Ramli Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: Mexico’s Judicial Reform Is Now In the Hands of Confused Voters
item.description: It’s an election unlike any other in Mexico. No sports stadiums packed with the party faithful. The smiling faces of normally omnipresent candidates almost completely absent on TV or glitzy posters. But the stakes couldn’t be higher.
item.dc:creator: Maya Averbuch, Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Advertisement promoting the judicial elections in Iztapalapa, Mexico City, Monday, May 12, 2025. Fred Ramos for Bloomberg

item.title: BOJ’s Bond Holding Paper Losses Hit Record After Rate Hikes
item.description: The Bank of Japan amassed the largest amount of unrealized losses on record from its government bond holdings in the year ended March, highlighting the challenges it faces in unwinding more than a decade of extraordinary monetary easing.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: the Bank of Japan headquarters in Tokyo.

item.title: Trump’s Nippon Steel Bid Support Boosts Japan’s Trade Talk Hopes
item.description: President Donald Trump’s pivot to champion Nippon Steel Corp.’s bid to buy US Steel Corp. raises the prospect of fresh positive momentum for Japan’s sluggish negotiations with the US over tariff relief.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: The US Steel Corp. Edgar Thomson Works in Braddock, Pennsylvania, US. Photographer: Justin Merriman/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea’s Lee Sees Lead Grow in Opinion Poll as Vote Looms
item.description: South Korea’s presidential frontrunner Lee Jae-myung increased his lead over ruling party nominee Kim Moon-soo, according to the latest opinion poll, another sign that he is well placed to triumph in next week’s election if the conservative vote remains split.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung arrives for a campaign event in Incheon, South Korea, on May 21. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Indonesia Open to Israel Ties if It Recognizes Palestine
item.description: Indonesia is ready to open diplomatic ties with Israel if it recognizes Palestinian statehood, President Prabowo Subianto said, indicating a shift in policy for the world’s most-populous Muslim-majority nation.
item.dc:creator: Chandra Asmara, Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: Pro-Palestinian protesters unfurl the Palestinian flag during a solidarity demonstration for Palestinian people in Bandung, West Java, Indonesia on April 20, 2025. The action aimed to protest Israel's attacks on Gaza, Palestine. They also called for a boycott of Israeli products and wanted a Free Palestine. (Photo by Dimas Rachmatsyah / Middle East Images / Middle East Images via AFP) (Photo by DIMAS RACHMATSYAH/Middle East Images/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: La Justicia en México pende de unos cuantos votantes confundidos
item.description: Elecciones sin precedentes: el domingo, los mexicanos elegirán a sus ministros y jueces
item.dc:creator: Maya Averbuch, Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Advertisement promoting the judicial elections in Iztapalapa, Mexico City, Monday, May 12, 2025. Fred Ramos for Bloomberg Photographer: FRED RAMOS

item.title: UK Envoy Urges Transatlantic Tech Alliance, Cites China Threat
item.description: The US and its allies across the Atlantic must forge a technology partnership and win the artificial intelligence race even as China makes steady advances, the UK’s envoy in Washington said.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: Peter Mandelson, British Ambassador to the US, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, May 8, 2025. US President Donald Trump announced a trade framework with the UK, hailing it as a "breakthrough" that will bring down barriers and expand market access for American imports. Photographer: Bonnie Cash/UPI/Bloomberg

item.title: China Tech Ambitions Won’t Hurt Consumption Pivot, Keyu Jin Says
item.description: China can boost production of high-end technological goods without undermining its push to lift domestic consumption, economist Keyu Jin said.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao

media:content.media:description: Economist Keyu Jin Photographer: Lluis Gene/Getty Images

item.title: Ukraine Needs $30 Billion to Boost Arms Output, Zelenskiy Says
item.description: Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskiy called on western allies to provide about $30 billion by the end of the year to boost domestic weapons production and hold off Russia’s advance.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska, Volodymyr Verbianyi

media:content.media:description: UNSPECIFIED, UKRAINE - FEBRUARY 21: Ukrainian soldiers of the 108th Territorial Defense Brigade test fly a Ukrainian-made Vampire drone, with six rotors, night vision and thermal imaging capabilities, and capable of carrying four 82mm artillery shells, near the southern frontline on February 21, 2024 in UNSPECIFIED, Zaporizhzhia Oblast, Ukraine. Russian forces have been mounting multiple attacks each day along the 600-mile frontline, while Ukrainian troops grapple with a shortage of ammunition and manpower. (Photo by Scott Peterson/Getty Images)

item.title: BBVA’s Sabadell Bid Delayed Further as Spain Starts Review
item.description: Spain’s government decided to conduct its own review of BBVA SA’s bid for rival Banco Sabadell SA, after the country’s antitrust watchdog last month cleared the offer with some conditions.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Zuloaga

media:content.media:description: A BBVA bank branch in Valencia, Spain.

item.title: US Ally South Korea Set to Improve China Ties If Lee Wins Vote
item.description: A win for the left-of-center frontrunner in South Korea’s presidential election would likely herald more caution by Seoul over taking sides in US-China rivalry, a new effort to draw North Korea into dialogue and the potential for tension with Japan.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung speaks at a campaign event in Uijeongbu on May 20.

item.title: Pessimism Swells on Doing Business in China, European Firms Say
item.description: European firms in China are the most pessimistic about growth prospects since 2011, a new survey shows, underscoring the challenges of doing business in the world’s second-largest economy despite recent government efforts to address some complaints.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu

item.title: Nigeria’s Tinubu Seeks Approval to Raise $24 Billion in Foreign Loans
item.description: Nigeria’s President Bola Tinubu has requested approval from lawmakers to raise almost $24 billion in external borrowing in the next two years to fund projects that will spur economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Nduka Orjinmo

media:content.media:description: Bola Tinubu

item.title: Australia’s Center-Right Opposition Regroups About One Week After Split
item.description: Australia’s center-right Liberal and National opposition parties have reassembled into a formal coalition, about a week after ending their decades-long alliance in the wake of a devastating national election loss.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott

media:content.media:description: Sussan Ley Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

item.title: US Poised to Get Golden Share in US Steel-Nippon Steel Deal
item.description: The US government is poised to receive a so-called golden share in United States Steel Corp. as a condition for approving Nippon Steel Corp.’s proposed acquisition of the American company.
item.dc:creator: Joe Deaux, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: The United States Steel Corp. facility in Clairton, Pennsylvania.

item.title: Indonesia, France Set to Sign Defense Letter During Macron Visit
item.description: Indonesia’s President Prabowo Subianto and France’s President Emmanuel Macron are poised to sign a letter of intent to strengthen a defense partnership that has already led to the Southeast Asian nation purchasing billions of dollars’ worth of French weaponry.
item.dc:creator: Chandra Asmara

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron and Prabowo Subianto in Jakarta on May 28. Photographer: Ludovic Marin/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Southeast Asia Voices ‘Urgency’ to Diversify Due to US Tariffs
item.description: Southeast Asian leaders called out President Donald Trump’s tariff plans as causing uncertainties in commerce with their region’s largest export customer and underscoring an “urgency of diversifying trade beyond traditional markets.”
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey, Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim, Malaysia's prime minister, left, and Zafrul Tengku Abdul Aziz, Malaysia's international trade and industry minister, during a news conference at the 46th Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) summit in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. Chinese Premier Li Qiang rallied a group of Southeast Asian and Gulf states to deepen cooperation, as the Asian nation ramps up its charm offensive abroad to counter US efforts to isolate the economy.

item.title: Poland Exposes Cracks in Its Booming Economy Before Crunch Vote
item.description: Donald Tusk’s government needs to keep businesses onside, and many want to see faster action on energy, bureaucracy and taxation.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko, Maciej Martewicz

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians near the entrance to a subway station in Warsaw, Poland, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Poland’s central bank cut interest rates for the first time since October 2023 as eastern Europe’s biggest economy prepares to elect a new president in a little over a week’s time.

item.title: Dismissing Putin as Crazy Is Deluded and Dangerous
item.description: The Kremlin’s recent escalation escalation is logical and, without a Trump U-turn, likely to succeed.
item.dc:creator: Marc Champion

media:content.media:description: In this pool photograph distributed by the Russian state agency Sputnik, Russia's President Vladimir Putin meets with representatives of the Russian business circles in Moscow on May 26, 2025. (Photo by Grigory SYSOYEV / POOL / AFP) (Photo by GRIGORY SYSOYEV/POOL/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Farage Keeps Finances Vague in UK Welfare Plan Targeting Labour
item.description: Nigel Farage made a clear attempt to win over Labour’s core working-class voters by calling for expanding welfare payments and cutting taxes. What was far less clear: How the Reform UK leader would pay for it without busting Britain’s budget.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Reform UK leader Nigel Farage Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Musk Says He’s ‘Disappointed’ That Trump Tax Bill Raises Deficit
item.description: Elon Musk expressed dissatisfaction with President Donald Trump’s giant tax bill, saying it undercut his efforts to slash government spending.
item.dc:creator: John Harney

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk and President Donald Trump in Washington, DC. Photographer: Aaron Schwartz/CNP

item.title: Trump Says Fannie Mae to Keep US Guarantee as Public Firm
item.description: President Donald Trump said that the US government would retain guarantees and an oversight role over Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac even as he pursues a public offering for the mortgage giants.
item.dc:creator: Derek Wallbank

media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - MAY 04: U.S. President Donald Trump speaks to reporters on the south lawn of the White House on May 04, 2025 in Washington, DC. The President spent the weekend in Florida and returned to Washington on Sunday. (Photo by Tasos Katopodis/Getty Images)

item.title: Hegseth Imposes Fresh Limits on Reporter Access to the Pentagon
item.description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth imposed a new round of restrictions on news outlets that cover the Pentagon, declaring large portions of the building off-limits to reporters unless they have an escort.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams

media:content.media:description: Pete Hegseth speaks during a ceremony at the Pentagon in Arlington, Virginia.
